title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forecast To Become Hurricane , Passing Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto was on its way to the Virgin Islands Tuesday afternoon, gaining strength as it swirled in the Atlantic Ocean, just days after Debby finished its trek along the U.S. East Coast.
Ernesto is expected to hit near or over the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday evening and become a hurricane while passing northeast of Puerto Rico later during the night, the National Hurricane Center says.
Ernesto is expected to hit near or over the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday evening and become a hurricane while passing northeast of Puerto Rico later during the night, the National Hurricane Center says.
A hurricane watch is in effect for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, and the islands Vieques and Culebra.
A tropical storm warning is in effect for St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat and Anguilla, as well as St. Martin and St. Barthelemy, Sint Maarten, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Vieques and Culebra.

title: Drought is top threat for united kingdom nature refuges as climate changes , charities warn
message:
Drought is now the biggest threat to important sites for nature across the UK as the climate changes, a report from The Wildlife Trusts has warned.
Over the next 30 years, Wildlife Trusts experts believe drought will continue to pose the biggest threat to their reserves, with other climate-driven risks including heatwaves and wildfires also causes for high concern.
The Wildlife Trusts warned that flooding, rather than drought, is often at the top of the list of hazards that politicians and governments use to discuss climate impacts.
Drought planning needs more urgent attention alongside the other key hazards associated with climate change, the report urges.
To protect against worsening extremes, The Wildlife Trusts say they are taking action across their reserves to make these important habitats for nature more resilient to the changing climate.

title: Governor Cooper : Lessons from past storms helped with Debby
message:
CRAVEN COUNTY, N.C. (WITN) - Governor Roy Cooper attended the North Carolina Commander’s Council meeting at Cherry Point on early Tuesday afternoon to listen to military commanders from across the state.
They discussed potential improvements for military bases and Cooper also commented on the aftermath of Tropical Storm Debby.
Many communities across Eastern Carolina are still experiencing the aftermath of tropical storm Debby.
Governor Cooper mentioned that his team learned valuable lessons from Hurricane Matthew and Florence, particularly in areas that continued to flood.
We want to rebuild as quickly as possible but we also want to rebuild in a smart way,” says Governor Cooper.
event_breakdown:
Craven County, North Carolina
Governor Roy Cooper attended North Carolina Commander’s Council meeting at Cherry Point. Attendees discussed potential improvements for military bases, governor's comments on aftermath of Tropical Storm Debby. Many communities across Eastern Carolina are still experiencing aftermath of tropical storm Debby. Governor Cooper mentioned learning valuable lessons from impacts of Hurricane Matthew and Florence, particularly in areas that didn’t perform well and continued to flood.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto brushes past Puerto Rico , poised to become hurricane
message:
Ernesto is forecast to become a hurricane overnight as the center of the storm moves just northeast of Puerto Rico on a path toward Bermuda.
“Since there is some chance of Ernesto becoming a hurricane while it is near the Virgin Islands, a hurricane watch remains in effect,” the U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami said.
After passing Puerto Rico, it is expected to move into open waters and be near Bermuda on Friday.
Ernesto was about 60 miles (95 kilometers) east-northeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico late Tuesday night.
Ernesto also forced the cancellation of dozens of flights to and from Puerto Rico.
event_breakdown: Ernesto

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto moves toward Puerto Rico after battering northeast Caribbean
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the U.S. territory's endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.
Ernesto is expected to become a hurricane overnight Tuesday as the center of the storm moves just northeast of Puerto Rico on a path toward Bermuda.
moved over the U.S. Virgin Islands on Tuesday night and is forecast to pass just northeast and north of Puerto Rico late Tuesday and early Wednesday.
Heavy rains began pelting Puerto Rico, and strong winds churned the ocean into a milky turquoise as people rushed to finish securing homes and businesses.
Ernesto also forced the cancellation of dozens of flights to and from Puerto Rico.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto battered Puerto Rico on Tuesday as it took aim at the U.S. territory, where officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms. Ernesto is also expected to become a hurricane overnight. Heavy rains and strong winds were hitting Puerto Rico, and churned ocean was turning into a milky turquoise as the storm forced dozens of flights to be cancelled to and from the island.

title: Sarasota County Schools Superintendent discusses goals for upcoming school year
message:
Prev NextPostedSarasota County Schools started classes on August 12.
ABC Action News anchor Nadeen Yanes sat down with Superintendent Terry Connor following the first day of school.
Superintendent Connor also spoke about the biggest challenge facing the district.
Connor told ABC Action News that following Hurricane Debby and major flooding in the county, 15 staff members and up to 50 families were impacted by the storm.

event_breakdown:
target event: AUSTRALIA FLOODS
Australia floods: Heavy rains have inundated rivers in Queensland and New South Wales, with Sydney among the worst affected areas.

New South Wales recorded heavy rainfalls from 16 to 21 March, drenching areas from the Queensland border up to northern parts of the state.

Flooding has prompted the evacuation of more than 1000 homes across the state, although no casualties have been reported so far.

Recovery efforts are underway, with the state government officially declaring these floods a natural disaster.

The town of Lismore has been hit hard with 9 of their bridges washed away. Three hundred Australian Defence force troops are now helping people in the parlour valley who have lost everything.

The state’s premier Dominic Perrottet has promised a relief package to help people to repair and rebuild their homes.

Catastrophic floods hit Queensland at the end of February - downing power lines, sweeping away roads and wiping out crops.

title: Bennettsville city leaders tackle frequent flooding , seek permanent solutions
message:
Bennettsville city leaders worked Monday and Tuesday to clean and dredge clogged ditches in communities that experience frequent flooding.
Many of the communities run along Crooked Creek, and during Tropical Storm Debby, several surrounding bodies of water flooded.
READ MORE:Due to the water overflow, residents say it also caused a stench which led to city leaders putting lime out to help the issue.
According to city leaders, crews used a street sweeper to clear the streets and pick up trash and debris.
Mayor Fowler said although the city is playing the waiting game to receive funding, he wants the community to know all city leaders are working to find a solution.

Ernesto was about 60 miles (95 kilometers) east-northeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico late Tuesday night.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forecast To Become Hurricane , Passing Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto was on its way to the Virgin Islands Tuesday afternoon, gaining strength as it swirled in the Atlantic Ocean, just days after Debby finished its trek along the U.S. East Coast.
Ernesto is expected to hit near or over the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday evening and become a hurricane while passing northeast of Puerto Rico later during the night, the National Hurricane Center says.
It was expected to be near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands by Tuesday evening and pass to the northeast and north of Puerto Rico on Tuesday and Wednesday.
A hurricane watch is in effect for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, and the islands Vieques and Culebra.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forecast To Become Hurricane , Passing Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto was on its way to the Virgin Islands Tuesday afternoon, gaining strength as it swirled in the Atlantic Ocean, just days after Debby finished its trek along the U.S. East Coast.
Ernesto is expected to hit near or over the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday evening and become a hurricane while passing northeast of Puerto Rico later during the night, the National Hurricane Center says.
It was expected to be near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands by Tuesday evening and pass to the northeast and north of Puerto Rico on Tuesday and Wednesday.
A hurricane watch is in effect for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, and the islands Vieques and Culebra.
A tropical storm warning is in effect for St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat and Anguilla, as well as St. Martin and St. Barthelemy, Sint Maarten, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Vieques and Culebra.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forms In Atlantic : Here 5 - Day Projected Path
message:
The projected timing and track of the tropical rainstorm through Friday evening, Aug. 16, is shown in the image above, just released late Monday by the National Hurricane Center.
The rainstorm is "forecast to intensify and bring heavy rainfall, gusty winds, and storm surge to parts of the Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, and the Dominican Republic this week," according to a statement by AccuWeather.com.
Formation chance through 48 hours is high at 70 percent and through seven days even higher at 90 percent, the National Hurricane Center said.
"After moving through the islands, the storm is forecast to be pulled to the north by a southward dip in the jet stream," AccuWeather Lead Hurricane Expert Alex DaSilva said.
"The storm may continue to intensify and could become the second major hurricane of the season by the end of this week."

title: Hurricane watch issued as Ernesto approaches Puerto Rico
message:
A red flag, indicating unsafe swimming conditions, is seen on the beach as waves crash onto the shore in Luquillo, Puerto Rico, on August 13, 2024, as Tropical Storm Ernesto approaches.
Ernesto is about 300 miles (480kms) east southeast of Puerto Rico, according to the US National Hurricane Center and predicts the storm will reach the island by late August 13.
The storm could become a hurricane within 12 hours, the NHC said — likely after it moves north of Puerto Rico.

title: FIRST ALERT : Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to reach hurricane strength by early Wednesday
message:
CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC/AP) - Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean and brushed past Puerto Rico, where officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the U.S. territory’s endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.
On the forecast track, the center of Ernesto will pass to the northeast and north of Puerto Rico through early Wednesday.

title: Drought is top threat for united kingdom nature refuges as climate changes , charities warn
message:
Over the next 30 years, Wildlife Trusts experts believe drought will continue to pose the biggest threat to their reserves, with other climate-driven risks including heatwaves and wildfires also causes for high concern.
The Wildlife Trusts warned that flooding, rather than drought, is often at the top of the list of hazards that politicians and governments use to discuss climate impacts.
Drought planning needs more urgent attention alongside the other key hazards associated with climate change, the report urges.
To protect against worsening extremes, The Wildlife Trusts say they are taking action across their reserves to make these important habitats for nature more resilient to the changing climate.
“We will better protect our landscapes and wildlife by taking robust action to prepare for the impacts of a changing climate.”

title: Hurricane watch issued as Ernesto approaches Puerto Rico
message:
Ernesto was about 300 miles (480 kms) east southeast of Puerto Rico, according to the US National Hurricane Center which predicted the storm will reach Puerto Rico by late August 13.
(Photos: AFP)MIAMI, United States (AFP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto advanced Tuesday through the Caribbean toward Puerto Rico, where officials shut down schools and sent workers home as forecasters warned of a possible hurricane.
It was expected to cross parts of the Lesser Antilles before approaching the US Virgin Islands, British Virgin Islands, and Puerto Rico Tuesday evening.
As a result, a hurricane watch had been issued for the Virgin Islands as well as Culebra and Vieques, two outlying islands off Puerto Rico.
Officials in Puerto Rico have already mobilised the National Guard, suspended classes in public schools, and sent home non-essential workers.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto near Puerto Rico.

title: Ernesto prompts hurricane alerts in northeast Caribbean , including Virgin Islands – ICSF
message:
Tropical storm warnings stretch from parts of the Leeward Islands into the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.
I​n addition, hurricane watches have been hoisted for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands as well as Culebra and Vieques.
Ernesto will spread westward from the Leeward Islands to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands through early Wednesday while intensifying.
Locally heavy rain and strong winds can be expected in the Leeward islands, including Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
A​ll interests from the Lesser Antilles to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands should prepare for strong winds and heavy rain.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Ernesto

A strengthening Tropical Storm Ernesto is expected to pass over the Leeward Islands on Tuesday, upgraded from a depression overnight, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.

At 5 a.m. EDT (0900 GMT) on Tuesday the center of the storm was about 85 miles (135 km) northeast of Puerto Rico and heading west-northwest at 23 mph (37 kph), the Miami-based forecaster said in a statement.

Ernesto, the NHC said, was expected to pass just north or north of Virgin Islands on Tuesday before approaching the Dominican Republic on Wednesday.

The upgrade follows a sharp overnight increase in maximum sustained winds to 45 mph (75 kph) with higher gusts.

The system is forecast to become a hurricane, the fourth of the 2012 Atlantic hurricane season.

The Leeward Islands, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands could make preparations for heavy rain and strong winds.

title: 20 years since Hurricane Charley left path of destruction across Florida
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. - Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2024, marked 20 years since Hurricane Charley made landfall in Southwest Florida at Punta Gorda as a Category 4 storm, wreaking havoc across the state.
Hurricane Charley just west of Fort Myer, Florida at 3:15 p.m., Aug. 13, 2004.
[Credit: NOAA]Charley was part of the infamous 2004 hurricane season, which also saw Hurricanes Jeanne, Frances, and Ivan batter the state.
During the night of August 12-13, Charley crossed western Cuba as a Category 2 hurricane with winds nearing 105 mph.
Path of Hurricane Charley in August of 2004.

Experts at The Wildlife Trusts are concerned about drought in England, warning that it will continue to pose the biggest threat to their reserves over the next 30 years, with other climate-driven risks including heatwaves and wildfires also causes for high concern.

The Wildlife Trusts urges for more urgent attention to be paid to drought-planning, as it is often ignored by governments in comparison to flooding that is discussed frequently.

Wildfires have been raging across a significant portion of British Columbia over the past week, including the raging wildfires in Central and Northern California, with heat, wind and drought contributing to its current state of emergency.

4. The watershed of Lake Powell

This month saw Lake Powell receiving a fourth of its annual typical flow of the Colorado River, with the watershed of the reservoir facing a megadrought that is now the worst natural disaster in the West.

5. Drought in New Zealand

New Zealand is expected to get drier over the next decade, and drought alerts have been issued for northern and central regions. Many residents are being urged to conserve water as drought is gripping the North Island.

title: Why Are Americans Still Willing to Move to Disaster Zones ?
message:
A net 16,144 people moved into U.S. counties with high flood risk last year, as defined by the climate-research firm First Street Foundation.
That’s a striking slowdown from the 383,656 who rushed into those places in 2021 and 2022.
As a result, Texas has the sixth-highest average annual premiums in the country, according to Bankrate.com.But these numbers are apparently still not high enough to change the minds of house-hunters.
One reason the number of billion-dollar disasters in this country keeps setting records is our dogged insistence on subsidizing the movement of houses, stores, offices and people into disaster zones.
Consumers need more information about the climate risks and potential insurance rates of the homes they want to buy.It won’t be easy.

Climate-research firm, First Street Foundation, reported an increase of 16,144 people moving in 2023 into the U.S. counties with high flood risk. The report highlighted a slowdown in this movement of people from 383,656 people in 2021 and 2022.

Tropical Storm Ernesto is currently located south of Puerto Rico, and is moving west-northwest at 16 mph. The storm has sustained winds of 60 mph, and is expected to continue moving west-northwest, passing just north of Puerto Rico on Saturday. As of noon on Saturday, the center of Ernesto was located about 80 miles east-southeast of St. Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands.

Ernesto, the second named storm of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season (which runs from June 1 to November 30), formed about 200 miles east of northern Leeward Islands on Thursday. The symptoms of the storm amplify it over a basin that includes Leeward Islands, Puerto Rico, U.S. Virgin Islands, southern Coastal Dominican Republic and Haiti. The storm is expected to pass north of the Dominican Republic and Haiti on Saturday, before heading to the eastern flank of Cuba. Tropical Storm warnings have been issued for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Vieques, and Culebra, as well as for the French departments of Martinique and Orientale. A tropical storm watch is in effect for Guadeloupe. Heavy rains could lead to floods and landslides in isolated areas such as Leeward Islands, northern Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Hispaniola, the southern coast of the Dominican Republic, islands in the Bahamas and the Turks & Caicos, and the Cuban provinces of Camaguea, Las Tunas, Holguin, and Granma.

title: Tropical storm Ernesto is poised to become a hurricane
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto was poised to become a hurricane shortly after brushing past Puerto Rico late Tuesday as officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the U.S. territory’s endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.
“Since there is some chance of Ernesto becoming a hurricane while it is near the Virgin Islands, a hurricane watch remains in effect,” the U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami said.
After passing Puerto Rico, it is expected to move into open waters and be near Bermuda on Friday.

title: Floodwater shuts down part of Highway 53 in Burgaw following Tropical Storm Debby
message:
BURGAW, N.C. (WECT) - After Tropical Storm Debby impacted the state, follow-up downpours added to the already swollen rivers.
Right now there’s nowhere for some of that water to go, leaving parts of Highway 53 impassable in some places.
According to Pender County Emergency Management Director Tommy Batson, the river crested at 16.51 ft on NC 53 at 4:15 a.m. Tuesday morning.
Batson adds that some parts of Hwy 53 are seeing five to six feet deep water.
“Anytime you got flooding, you got to pack up and get,” said Doug Dicksey, who lives off Highway 53.

Tropical Storm Ernesto leaves hundreds of thousands without power in Puerto RicoPosted/updated on: August 14, 2024 at 9:01 amABC News(NEW YORK) -- The center of Tropical Storm Ernesto passed within 40 miles from San Juan, Puerto Rico, producing strong winds and heavy rain overnight.
More than 570,000 customers were without power in Puerto Rico, according to LUMA, a service provider.
The storm was moving away from Puerto Rico on Wednesday morning and nearing hurricane strength with sustained winds of 70 mph.

The NHC says Hurricane Ernesto is expected to strengthen over the next few days and could become a major hurricane (Category 3 or higher).

title: Ernesto becomes a hurricane after drenching Puerto Rico
message:
Downed power lines are seen after Tropical Storm Ernesto moved through the area in Fajardo, Puerto Rico, on August 14, 2024.
(Photo: AFP)MIAMI, United States (AFP) — Ernesto grew into a hurricane Wednesday, US forecasters said, after leaving more than 600,000 customers without power in the US territory of Puerto Rico.
The storm left some 604,000 customers in Puerto Rico without electricity, according to power company Luma Energy.
The Puerto Rican power grid has suffered frequent outages since Category 4 Hurricane Maria tore through it in 2017.
The NHC said the nearby Virgin Islands could also see “significant flooding.” Both the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico remained under a tropical storm warning.

title: Ernesto to become a major hurricane , threaten Bermuda , Canada
message:
At 2 p.m. EDT, Wednesday Ernesto was a Category 1 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson hurricane wind scale with 75 mph maximum sustained winds while tracking away from Puerto Rico.
After Ernesto's encounter with Bermuda this weekend, the next stop for the hurricane will be Atlantic Canada.
At this time, landfall could occur as early as late Sunday night to late Monday in Atlantic Canada.
While waters trend progressively cooler north of Bermuda, they are warm enough to sustain a quick-moving hurricane such as Ernesto.
However, should Ernesto and the jet stream merge over Atlantic Canada, rainfall could increase exponentially, and a widespread major flooding event might unfold with significant risk to lives and property.

title: Ernesto strengthens to third hurricane of 2024 Atlantic season
message:
BRYAN, Texas (KBTX) - Upon data received from the Air Force Reserve Hurricane Hunter aircraft, Tropical Storm Ernesto was upgraded to a category 1 hurricane as of Wednesday morning.
Ernesto became a hurricane just north of Puerto Rico, meaning that significant flooding there and the Virgin Islands is expected due to its proximity and heavy rainfall.
Beyond that, the hurricane’s maximum sustained winds are currently measured at 75 mph, with the aforementioned areas experiencing tropical storm force winds as they are left in Ernesto’s wake.
Ernesto strengthens to a hurricane just north of Puerto Rico.
This trough will then leave Ernesto behind, causing it to slow down and strengthen as it approaches Bermuda within the next 48 hours.
event_breakdown:
Following that data received from the Air Force Reserve Hurricane Hunter aircraft, Tropical Storm Ernesto was upgraded to a category 1 hurricane on Wednesday morning.
However, Ernesto was likely not strong enough to be reported much. Its maximum sustained winds are currently measured at 75 mph, with the aforementioned areas experiencing tropical storm force winds as they are left in Ernesto’s wake.
Ernesto is about 1,400 miles from the deep tropical Atlantic, where meteorologists are monitoring another area expected to soon develop into a tropical or subtropical storm. If it does, it would likely garner a tropical or subtropical storm name that should signal more effective effect on land.

title: Ernesto Lashes Puerto Rico As It Strengthens Into Hurricane
message:
Hurricane Ernesto, the fifth named storm of this year's Atlantic hurricane season, has left thousands without power in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
Ernesto has caused significant flooding in Puerto Rico, with the island's Rio Grande de Loiza and Rio Blanco rivers overflowing.
Nearly 46,000 people in the Virgin Islands and more than 660,000 in Puerto Rico are without power.
President Biden has approved an emergency declaration for Puerto Rico, authorizing the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to assist with storm recovery.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has predicted an above-average Atlantic hurricane season this year due to record-warm ocean temperatures.

First Prev 1 2 3 Next LastThe Wednesday 6am update on Tropical Storm Ernesto, which is growing into a hurricane as it heads on a direct course for Bermuda (Photograph courtesy of the Bermuda Weather Service)Tropical Storm Ernesto has been upgraded as a threat to Bermuda.
After passing over Bermuda, Ernesto is expected to turn to Newfoundland, Canada, by next week.
Tropical Storm Ernesto is the fifth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, following Hurricane Beryl, Hurricane Debby, Tropical Storm Alberto and Tropical Storm Chris.
The NHC forecast an 85 per cent chance of a busier-than-average season with between 17 and 25 named storms, while Britain’s Met Office forecast 22 named storms during the season.
The track of Tropical Storm Ernesto according to the weather website Windy.co.

title: Ernesto Becomes Hurricane | News Talk 99 . 5 WRNO | Operation Stormwatch : New Orleans
message:
The National Hurricane Center says the storm system Ernesto is now a hurricane.
The system has been hitting eastern Puerto Rico with torrential rainfall.
The NHC says significant flooding is expected across Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
As of the 10 a.m. Wednesday update, Ernesto had maximum sustained winds of 75 miles per hour.
Forecasters say Ernesto's winds could peak at 115 miles per hour in the next 48 hours, which would be make the system a major category 3 hurricane.
event_breakdown: National Hurricane Center says storm system Ernesto is now a hurricane, and it is expected to intensify into a category three hurricane within the next 48 hours. Significant flooding is expected across Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: Next  major hurricane  may be forming : What you need to know about Tropical Storm Ernesto
message:
Following closely on the heels of the deadly Hurricane Debby, as of Wednesday morning, Tropical Storm Ernesto is battering the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico with tropical storm conditions expected to produce flooding, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).
Initially dubbed a tropical rainstorm by AccuWeather, Ernesto evolved into a tropical storm Monday evening.
An AccuWeather graphic shows anticipated rainfall amounts from Tropical Storm Ernesto from Saturday, Aug. 10, through Sunday, Aug. 18, 2024.
Thanks to light wind shear, Ernesto is forecasted by AccuWeather to maintain tropical storm strength as it passes through the Caribbean.
An AccuWeather graphic shows anticipated wind gusts from Tropical Storm Ernesto through Sunday, Aug. 18, 2024.

Natural-disasters:
- Tropical Storm Ernesto is battering the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico and is forecasted to maintain tropical storm strength as it passes through the Caribbean.

title: FEMA Disaster Relief Fund is out of money , agency says
message:
(Gray News) - As another storm is impacting U.S. territories, the Federal Emergency Management Agency announced Tuesday its disaster fund has run out of money.
The agency’s administrator, Deanne Criswell, said for now, FEMA will only provide money for immediate needs, which is described as “lifesaving and life-sustaining activities.”She said she hopes Congress will pass a $9 billion supplemental request to help restore funding for its disaster fund.
This is the second year in a row that FEMA’s disaster fund has run out of money before the full force of hurricane season takes effect.
Peak hurricane season for the Atlantic basin is Sept. 10, with most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, the National Hurricane Center said.
FEMA said it’s reached the point of operating under an immediate needs funding restriction nine times since 2001.
location: FEMA's disaster fund has run out again before the main hurricane season.

title: Ernesto becomes Category 1 hurricane , expected to strengthen
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. – Ernesto strengthened into a Category 1 hurricane Wednesday, after bringing flooding rains across Puerto Rico.
According to the National Hurricane Center, Ernesto has maximum sustained winds of 75 mph and was located about 175 miles northwest of San Juan, Puerto Rico.
It is expected to become a major hurricane in a couple of days.
A hurricane is considered a major hurricane when it reaches Category 3 status.
Here is what determines each category for a hurricane:Category 1: 74 to 95 mph sustained windsCategory 2: 96 to 110 mph sustained windsCategory 3: 111 to 129 mph sustained windsCategory 4: 130 to 156 mph sustained windsCategory 5: 157 mph or higher sustained windsErnesto is expected to move over the western Atlantic later this week and near Bermuda on Saturday.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Drenches Puerto Rico on Path Northward
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto pounded Puerto Rico with torrential rain and winds as it brushed by the island on a track that’s likely to see it become a hurricane later Wednesday.
Ernesto was about 85 miles (135 kilometers) north-northwest of San Juan by 5 a.m. local time, the US National Hurricane Center said in an advisory.
It’s expected to turn northward and move over the western Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda later in the week.
Coastal flooding is possible in areas including eastern Puerto Rico and in the neighboring US Virgin Islands.
Puerto Rico has endured a series of powerful storms in recent years that have repeatedly battered its fragile power grid and disrupted its economy.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto is battering Puerto Rico, in the US Caribbean.

title: Summer rains , Tropical Storm Debby relieve drought across South Carolina
message:
COLUMBIA, S.C. (WIS) - The South Carolina Department of Resources (SCDNR) announced Tuesday that much of the Palmetto State is free from drought after summer rains drenched the region in late July.
In early July, SCDNR’s Drought Response Committee said all 46 counties within South Carolina were experiencing some level of drought due to the intense summer conditions.
Several Midlands farmers felt the pressure, especially those counties which were in severe drought like Calhoun, Clarendon, Sumter, Lee and Kershaw counties.
However, the Committee’s Tuesday meeting downgraded 38 state counties to normal conditions following a slew of scattered storms and downpours associated with Tropical Storm Debby.
Officials with the South Carolina State Climatology Office presented data showing Tropical Storm Debby brought between five to ten inches of rain to most of the state, with some locations reporting between 15 to 20 inches.
event_breakdown: South Carolina Drought Ends: South Carolina’s Drought Response Committee downgraded 38 counties to normal after a string of summer showers and storms arrived from Tropical Storm Debby.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto pummels northeast Caribbean leaving hundreds of thousands in the dark
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto dropped torrential rain on Puerto Rico on Wednesday and left hundreds of thousands of people without power in the US territory as it threatened to strengthen into a major hurricane en route to Bermuda.
The storm was located about 125 miles (200 kilometres) northwest of San Juan, Puerto Rico and was moving over open waters.
A tropical storm warning was in effect for Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra and the US and British Virgin Islands.
The government of the US Virgin Islands reported an island-wide blackout in St Croix, while in Puerto Rico, more than 300,000 customers were without power.
Puerto Rico Governor Pedro Pierluisi announced late Tuesday that US President Joe Biden had approved his request to use emergency FEMA funds as a result of the tropical storm.

Hurricane Irma:
Strengthening Hurricane Irma continued its destructive path across the Caribbean Friday, leaving at least 22 people dead. The Category 5 storm — the strongest in a decade — rammed into a string of northern Caribbean islands early Wednesday, with winds of up to 185 mph, leaving Barbuda, St. Martin, St. Barthélemy, the US and British Virgin Islands, as well as Puerto Rico and Anguilla devastated.
Earthquakes in Mexico:
A powerful earthquake that rattled Mexico on Thursday has caused widespread damage, killing at least 85 people. The magnitude 8.1 quake hit late Thursday evening, killing 58 people in neighboring Oaxaca. More than 100 people were still missing. There have also been powerful aftershocks of magnitude 5.2 and 6.1.

San Juan, Puerto Rico, radar loop from around 2 PM local Tuesday to 8 AM local Wednesday.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto was gaining strength in the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday and was expected to turn toward the United States, forecasters said.
Forecasters said the storm is expected to be a major hurricane within 48 hours but was generating only tropical-storm force winds for now.
The storm was located about 175 miles (280 kilometers) northwest of San Juan, Puerto Rico and was moving over open waters.
A tropical storm warning was in effect Wednesday for Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands and British Virgin Islands. Authorities issued a red alert for heavy rains in the territory.
Nearly 100 flights also were canceled to and from Puerto Rico.
Puerto Rico Gov. Alejandro Garcia Padilla warned that dangerous surf, landslides and swollen rivers were expected from the rains. Garcia urged people to stay alert and avoid mountainous areas.
Puerto Rico's Electric Utilities Authority also said the storm might knock down power lines.

title: Ernesto becomes hurricane after leaving 570 , 000 without power in Puerto Rico
message:
ABC News(NEW YORK) — Ernesto has become a Category 1 hurricane Wednesday after hitting Puerto Rico overnight and leaving power outages and flooding in its wake.
The center of then-Tropical Storm Ernesto passed within 40 miles of San Juan, Puerto Rico, early Wednesday, producing strong winds and heavy rain.
More than 570,000 customers are without power in Puerto Rico, according to LUMA, a service provider.
The storm was moving away from Puerto Rico on Wednesday morning with hurricane strength winds of 75 mph.
Tropical storm warnings were issued for Puerto Rico and a hurricane watch was in effect for the British Virgin Islands.

title: FEMA Disaster Relief Fund is out of money , agency says
message:
(Gray News) - As another storm is impacting U.S. territories, the Federal Emergency Management Agency announced Tuesday its disaster fund has run out of money.
The agency’s administrator, Deanne Criswell, said for now, FEMA will only provide money for immediate needs, which is described as “lifesaving and life-sustaining activities.”She said she hopes Congress will pass a $9 billion supplemental request to help restore funding for its disaster fund.
This is the second year in a row that FEMA’s disaster fund has run out of money before the full force of hurricane season takes effect.
Peak hurricane season for the Atlantic basin is Sept. 10, with most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, the National Hurricane Center said.
FEMA said it’s reached the point of operating under an immediate needs funding restriction nine times since 2001.
